div1.p: Lazear describes life in California. He discusses the weather and his acquaintances.

div1.head: Letter from Jesse W. Lazear to Charlotte C. Sweitzer, July 23, 1896
div1.p:
I am
writing this at Patter's
Valley, a small village
15 miles from the
Lierley Ranch. I walked
here this morning
and shall return by
the stage this afternoon.
Your letter of July 7
came on the day
I mailed my last
letter to you. I was
glad to hear from
you and to learn
that you were all
right.

We are having much
cooler weather now.
The entire absence
of rain seems very
strange to me. Hammocks
books clothes etc
are left out of doors
with impunity.

Of course it is very dusty. One
has to wear leggings on account
of the dust and as a protection
against rattlesnakes. I saw
one yesterday for the first
time. They are big lazy things
and do not seem to want to
fight. The rattle one hears
about is a very insignificant
affair. I have not yet
killed my deer but I have
not tried very hard to find
one. Pretty soon I shall
make an expedition up the
mountain where they are
plentiful. I have had very
good luck at trout fishing.
I caugh twenty four fine ones
yesterday morning.

Mabel is a very
good woodswoman
She walks and climbs
well in her short
skirts and leggings.
We are really out
in the wilderness
many miles from
any neighbors, the
country is all rough
and mountainous
Mrs. Houston not
being a good walker
has rather a hard
time of it. Nellie
Houston also does
not feel at home
She spends most
of her time reading.
There are some other
people here who seem
very pleasant but I
do not see much
of any of them except
of a Miss Hyde a
friend of the Houstons
and Dr. Russell of
Oakland, California who is
very nice indeed indeed.
Altogether, I am having a
very pleasant time seeing a
good deal of Mabel which is
the chief thing desired. We
are really very congenial,
more so even than I had
hoped expected.

It is rather hard for me
to write regularly. My tent
although delightful at night
is not habitable in the day
time owing to the heat.
However I shall try to
get one off every week.
